article.headline: (15) OKLAHOMA 69, EASTERN WASH 59
article.story: NORMAN, Okla. (AP) -- The Oklahoma Sooners needed a little time to get warmed up in their season opener. DeAngelo Alexander scored 18 points to help No. 14 Oklahoma rally to beat Eastern Washington 69-59 on Friday night in the first round of the Sooner Invitational. "That's part of basketball. It was a total team effort," Alexander said. "The team dug in and came together. We had to get stops on defense. That was a big part of the ballgame." The Sooners, who trailed by as many as 13 points in the first half, finished with a 10-1 run. "We knew they were a good team. It was a good win for us," coach Kelvin Sampson said. "During the month of November, you have to understand the way this thing works. "We knew after watching film the last two weeks that they were going to be tough. Coach Ray Giacoletti does an excellent job. They remind me a lot of my old Washington State teams the way they spread the floor and run the offense. They execute." Drew Lavender added 12 points for the Sooners, and Jaison Williams had 10. Josh Barnard scored 14 of his 17 points in the first half for the Eagles, and Alvin Snow added 13. Eastern Washington took a 13-2 lead and led by three at the half. Oklahoma took its first lead on Kevin Bookout's layup with 4:40 remaining in the game. "I believe we just need to do a better job of finishing things," Giacoletti said. "I'll take the blame at the end. I need to do a better job at communicating what we need to be doing." Oklahoma, 9-1 in season openers under Sampson, will face Oral Roberts in the championship game Saturday night. Oral Roberts beat South Carolina State 63-60. Oklahoma guard Jason Detrick missed the game because of abdominal injury. "A lot of stuff we're going through is that our freshmen are growing up," Sampson said. "Our team is a work in progress. At one point, we had three freshmen and two sophomores on the floor. You would think I was coaching a junior college. We're young and it will take us a while to jell."
